full_text: @autismwessex Many surveys have shown that “autistic person “ is preferred by the autistic community (not the “autism community”). “Autistic person” is the language recommended by the National Autistic Society, the NHS, the NICE, and by autistic-led organisations such as Autistic UK.
full_text(utf-8): b'@autismwessex Many surveys have shown that \xe2\x80\x9cautistic person \xe2\x80\x9c is preferred by the autistic community (not the \xe2\x80\x9cautism community\xe2\x80\x9d). \xe2\x80\x9cAutistic person\xe2\x80\x9d is the language recommended by the National Autistic Society, the NHS, the NICE, and by autistic-led organisations such as Autistic UK.'

full_text: @BRMaycock @SJ_Watson It’s fine! 😊

full_text: @BRMaycock @SJ_Watson You’re absolutely right, that’s why I said “tends to be pretty unpopular” rather than “is universally disliked”, and stressed that personal preference varies 🙂
full_text(utf-8): b'@BRMaycock @SJ_Watson You\xe2\x80\x99re absolutely right, that\xe2\x80\x99s why I said \xe2\x80\x9ctends to be pretty unpopular\xe2\x80\x9d rather than \xe2\x80\x9cis universally disliked\xe2\x80\x9d, and stressed that personal preference varies \xf0\x9f\x99\x82'

full_text: @SJ_Watson Autistic-led organisations such as Autistic UK and the Autistic Self-Advocacy Network also pretty much exclusively use identity-first language (“autistic”).
full_text(utf-8): b'@SJ_Watson Autistic-led organisations such as Autistic UK and the Autistic Self-Advocacy Network also pretty much exclusively use identity-first language (\xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d).'

full_text: @SJ_Watson Absolutely and under all circumstances avoid phrasing such as “living with/suffering from/experiencing autism”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SJ_Watson Absolutely and under all circumstances avoid phrasing such as \xe2\x80\x9cliving with/suffering from/experiencing autism\xe2\x80\x9d.'

full_text: @SJ_Watson As an aside, an individual is generally “neurodivergent”, with a population/group being “neurodiverse”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SJ_Watson As an aside, an individual is generally \xe2\x80\x9cneurodivergent\xe2\x80\x9d, with a population/group being \xe2\x80\x9cneurodiverse\xe2\x80\x9d.'

full_text: @SJ_Watson You may find many non-autistic professionals and family members prefer person-first language (“has autism”/“with autism”), but this wording tends to be pretty unpopular amongst autistic people.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SJ_Watson You may find many non-autistic professionals and family members prefer person-first language (\xe2\x80\x9chas autism\xe2\x80\x9d/\xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d), but this wording tends to be pretty unpopular amongst autistic people.'

full_text: @SJ_Watson “Autistic” (adjective) is the most popular wording amongst autistic people. The NICE, NHS, and National Autistic Society all have language guidelines which recommend using this language by default, or when speaking in general terms (obviously personal preference varies).
full_text(utf-8): b'@SJ_Watson \xe2\x80\x9cAutistic\xe2\x80\x9d (adjective) is the most popular wording amongst autistic people. full_text: @word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews I could go on. Oppression and discrimination against autistic people exists in virtually every area of society.
full_text(utf-8): b'@word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews I could go on. Oppression and discrimination against autistic people exists in virtually every area of society.'

full_text: @word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews In some places autistic people cannot foster or adopt children. If a parent discloses they are autistic they are more likely to be investigated or treated with suspicion by social services. We are less likely to have medical issues taken seriously.
full_text(utf-8): b'@word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews In some places autistic people cannot foster or adopt children. If a parent discloses they are autistic they are more likely to be investigated or treated with suspicion by social services. We are less likely to have medical issues taken seriously.'

full_text: @word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews Autistic adults have much higher unemployment rates, largely due to stress and stress and other mental health issues caused by lack of accommodations. Many countries will not accept autistic immigrants. We are often banned from certain careers (military etc).
full_text(utf-8): b'@word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews Autistic adults have much higher unemployment rates, largely due to stress and stress and other mental health issues caused by lack of accommodations. Many countries will not accept autistic immigrants. We are often banned from certain careers (military etc).'

full_text: @word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews Also, autistic children are murdered at a higher rate than typically developing children, usually by parents or caregivers. They are denied access to alternative means of communication and forced to “mask” to make allistic people more comfortable (eye-contact etc).
full_text(utf-8): b'@word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews Also, autistic children are murdered at a higher rate than typically developing children, usually by parents or caregivers. They are denied access to alternative means of communication and forced to \xe2\x80\x9cmask\xe2\x80\x9d to make allistic people more comfortable (eye-contact etc).'

full_text: @word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews As others have pointed out, people-first language is extremely unpopular in the autistic community. The fact that we’re so vocal about this and yet it continues to be taught as the correct way to speak about us is just one tiny way we are oppressed.
full_text(utf-8): b'@word_document1 @DWAMURRAY @CBSNews As others have pointed out, people-first language is extremely unpopular in the autistic community. The fact that we\xe2\x80\x99re so vocal about this and yet it continues to be taught as the correct way to speak about us is just one tiny way we are oppressed.'

full_text(utf-8): b'@JFKrateZ @aheeleyRIBA If you look at autistic-led organisations such as ASAN and AWN they all tend to use \xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d pretty much exclusively. full_text: @allisonching1 @aheeleyRIBA @BabyBloomNutrit @JesseLunsford As long as you defer to the individual wherever possible and don’t insist on speaking over people who prefer something different, you’re probably fine 🙂 Most people only get cross when someone tries to correct them.
full_text(utf-8): b'@allisonching1 @aheeleyRIBA @BabyBloomNutrit @JesseLunsford As long as you defer to the individual wherever possible and don\xe2\x80\x99t insist on speaking over people who prefer something different, you\xe2\x80\x99re probably fine \xf0\x9f\x99\x82 Most people only get cross when someone tries to correct them.'

full_text: @allisonching1 @aheeleyRIBA @BabyBloomNutrit @JesseLunsford Unfortunately some people will take offence no matter which term you choose. “Has autism”/“with autism” is more likely to offend autistic people, whereas “autistic” is more likely to offend non-autistic people such as parents and professionals.

full_text: @JazzLeigh1 @maya_echo @FranziaMom Obviously personal preference is the most important thing, but when it comes to autism I’d definitely consider person-first language to be the more outdated phrasing.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JazzLeigh1 @maya_echo @FranziaMom Obviously personal preference is the most important thing, but when it comes to autism I\xe2\x80\x99d definitely consider person-first language to be the more outdated phrasing.'

full_text: @JazzLeigh1 @maya_echo @FranziaMom If you look at autistic-led organisations they  all tend to use this wording too. “People with autism” tends to be mostly used by non-autistic parents and professionals. There’s been pushback against it from autistic advocates for at least twenty years.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JazzLeigh1 @maya_echo @FranziaMom If you look at autistic-led organisations they  all tend to use this wording too. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople with autism\xe2\x80\x9d tends to be mostly used by non-autistic parents and professionals. There\xe2\x80\x99s been pushback against it from autistic advocates for at least twenty years.'

full_text: @JazzLeigh1 @maya_echo @FranziaMom Obviously it’s down to personal preference and some people do prefer person-first language, but generally speaking it’s very unpopular in the autistic community. In my experience in autistic spaces the wording “autistic people” is used almost exclusively.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JazzLeigh1 @maya_echo @FranziaMom Obviously it\xe2\x80\x99s down to personal preference and some people do prefer person-first language, but generally speaking it\xe2\x80\x99s very unpopular in the autistic community. full_text: @edensbrother @FranziaMom Simplest way to explain is to think of it like saying “person with bisexuality” or “person with creativeness” instead of “bisexual person” or “creative person”. It’s not an external thing, it’s part of who someone is. Why avoid using the adjective?

full_text: @austynTx @aheeleyRIBA Yes, it is. “People with autism” tends to be preferred by a lot of non-autistic parents and professionals, but most autistic people prefer “autistic people”. full_text: @CarmCollective @sapientVirgo @BDUTT @ashappillai @WeTheWomenAsia @themojo_in Of course, some people do,prefer the wording “with/has autism” and that’s totally valid, but it’s definitely not the rule.
full_text(utf-8): b'@CarmCollective @sapientVirgo @BDUTT @ashappillai @WeTheWomenAsia @themojo_in Of course, some people do,prefer the wording \xe2\x80\x9cwith/has autism\xe2\x80\x9d and that\xe2\x80\x99s totally valid, but it\xe2\x80\x99s definitely not the rule.'

full_text: @CarmCollective @sapientVirgo @BDUTT @ashappillai @WeTheWomenAsia @themojo_in Exactly this. Autism is not a disease and the majority of autistic people prefer “is autistic” to “has autism”. Language like “suffering from autism” is considered offensive, as is comparing autism to things like cancer. It’s not something we have, it’s who we are.
full_text(utf-8): b'@CarmCollective @sapientVirgo @BDUTT @ashappillai @WeTheWomenAsia @themojo_in Exactly this. full_text: @muninnherself In the upper sixth we didn't wear uniform but were supposed to dress very smartly, "as if attending a job interview or meeting with your bank manager". In practice people often got away with slightly less formal. Girls could not wear trousers under any circumstances.
full_text(utf-8): b'@muninnherself In the upper sixth we didn\'t wear uniform but were supposed to dress very smartly, "as if attending a job interview or meeting with your bank manager". full_text: @muninnherself grey skirt (possibly navy too?) , as long as it was deemed "appropriate" (not too long, short, casual etc).  I think we could wear any white shirt, not just the regulation school ones. Light blue may have been ok too, I can't remember.

full_text: @tlhoff99 @maya_echo Obviously some people do prefer person-first language for themselves and that’s absolutely their right, but this kind of language is widely seen as stigmatising and  degrading in the autistic community.
full_text(utf-8): b'@tlhoff99 @maya_echo Obviously some people do prefer person-first language for themselves and that\xe2\x80\x99s absolutely their right, but this kind of language is widely seen as stigmatising and  degrading in the autistic community.'

full_text: @tlhoff99 @maya_echo The thing is, a lot of autistic people don’t think about autism in these terms. For many of us, it absolutely defines us because it’s literally the way our brains are wired, so you don’t need to linguistically separate the “person” and the “autism” when speaking about us.
full_text(utf-8): b'@tlhoff99 @maya_echo The thing is, a lot of autistic people don\xe2\x80\x99t think about autism in these terms. full_text: @CheerioWorld It’s very much personal choice, and you can’t apply one rule to all conditions/disabilities. I am autistic and I also have anxiety. I wouldn’t describe myself as a “person with autism” or an “anxious person”. Being autistic is who I am, whereas anxiety is something I have.
full_text(utf-8): b'@CheerioWorld It\xe2\x80\x99s very much personal choice, and you can\xe2\x80\x99t apply one rule to all conditions/disabilities. I am autistic and I also have anxiety. full_text: @Juliamericaine @ShaunLintern I don’t think it’s necessarily a UK/US thing. American autistic-led organisations such as ASAN and AWN are also proponents of identity/condition-first language.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Juliamericaine @ShaunLintern I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s necessarily a UK/US thing. American autistic-led organisations such as ASAN and AWN are also proponents of identity/condition-first language.'

full_text: @Juliamericaine @ShaunLintern Why? Most autistic people tend to prefer “autistic” so unless you happen to know that the person in question prefers person-first then it shouldn’t need correcting. The National Autistic Society, NHS and NICE language guidelines all support this.

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo I don’t think anything approaching a decent understanding of autism could be present in the 1-3 words we use to describe it tbh. People are educated on it or they’re not. I don’t care for the term ASD personally, although I don’t necessarily mind references to “the spectrum”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo I don\xe2\x80\x99t think anything approaching a decent understanding of autism could be present in the 1-3 words we use to describe it tbh. People are educated on it or they\xe2\x80\x99re not. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care for the term ASD personally, although I don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily mind references to \xe2\x80\x9cthe spectrum\xe2\x80\x9d.'

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo It’s very odd. In English it’s quite usual for adjectives to come before a noun. Nobody has a problem with saying “normal people” or “tall people” or “British people”, and we don’t refer to gay people as “people with homosexuality”. 🤷‍♀️
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo It\xe2\x80\x99s very odd. In English it\xe2\x80\x99s quite usual for adjectives to come before a noun. Nobody has a problem with saying \xe2\x80\x9cnormal people\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9ctall people\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cBritish people\xe2\x80\x9d, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t refer to gay people as \xe2\x80\x9cpeople with homosexuality\xe2\x80\x9d. \xf0\x9f\xa4\xb7\xe2\x80\x8d\xe2\x99\x80\xef\xb8\x8f'

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo I don’t think “autistic” conflicts with the idea of the spectrum. It’s not like the word “spectrum” is all that helpful anyway because it implies a linear progression from “not at all autistic” to “very autistic” which is inaccurate and leads to harmful assumptions.
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo I don\xe2\x80\x99t think \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d conflicts with the idea of the spectrum. It\xe2\x80\x99s not like the word \xe2\x80\x9cspectrum\xe2\x80\x9d is all that helpful anyway because it implies a linear progression from \xe2\x80\x9cnot at all autistic\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cvery autistic\xe2\x80\x9d which is inaccurate and leads to harmful assumptions.'

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo I don’t know any autistics who are ok with the puzzle symbol or the analogy (although I’m sure they exist). It will likely persist as long as fields such as academia and special education continue to speak over autistic people, and I don’t see that changing any time soon.
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo I don\xe2\x80\x99t know any autistics who are ok with the puzzle symbol or the analogy (although I\xe2\x80\x99m sure they exist). full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo I mean, many people don’t care one way or the other. It’s the rationale between person-first that’s the problem, more than the wording itself. The idea that someone has to be seen as separate from their autism to have value is hugely offensive and damaging.
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo I mean, many people don\xe2\x80\x99t care one way or the other. It\xe2\x80\x99s the rationale between person-first that\xe2\x80\x99s the problem, more than the wording itself. The idea that someone has to be seen as separate from their autism to have value is hugely offensive and damaging.'

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo The narrative surrounding autism is dominated by organisations such as Autism Speaks. People look to them for information not realising that they don’t represent autistic people in any way and are widely considered harmful (to put it very mildly).
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo The narrative surrounding autism is dominated by organisations such as Autism Speaks. People look to them for information not realising that they don\xe2\x80\x99t represent autistic people in any way and are widely considered harmful (to put it very mildly).'

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo They consider the opinions of other non-autistic people to be more important than those of us with lived experience, and don’t believe we are in a position to fully understand our own lives.
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo They consider the opinions of other non-autistic people to be more important than those of us with lived experience, and don\xe2\x80\x99t believe we are in a position to fully understand our own lives.'

full_text: @DAllen_94 @maya_echo Thank you! The problem, simply-put, seems to be the paternalistic attitude of non-autistic educators towards autistic people. They do not engage with us or consider our opinions worthy of respect, preferring to talk *about* us rather then *to* us.
full_text(utf-8): b'@DAllen_94 @maya_echo Thank you! The problem, simply-put, seems to be the paternalistic attitude of non-autistic educators towards autistic people. They do not engage with us or consider our opinions worthy of respect, preferring to talk *about* us rather then *to* us.'

full_text: @DAllen_94 It’s not outdated at all. The last couple of decades have seen a significant shift away from person-first language in the autistic community. Try engaging with autistic-led organisations to see what they have to say on the matter.

full_text: @CEOofNEGATIVITY @feelinfroggy181 @LegalBeagle1215 As I said, some autistic people do prefer PFL for themselves and that’s their choice. full_text(utf-8): b'@CEOofNEGATIVITY @feelinfroggy181 @LegalBeagle1215 As I said, some autistic people do prefer PFL for themselves and that\xe2\x80\x99s their choice. full_text: @CEOofNEGATIVITY @feelinfroggy181 @LegalBeagle1215 Obviously it has its place, but there has been pushback against PFL from autistic people for over two decades. Look at the language used by autistic-led organisations - they all talk about “autistic people” rather than “people with autism”. There’s been a lot written about this.
full_text(utf-8): b'@CEOofNEGATIVITY @feelinfroggy181 @LegalBeagle1215 Obviously it has its place, but there has been pushback against PFL from autistic people for over two decades. full_text: @CEOofNEGATIVITY @feelinfroggy181 @LegalBeagle1215 Any PFL seminar worth its salt should acknowledge that it’s not a hard-and-fast rule and that language is a very personal choice. full_text: @JezzChung Everyone has their own preference! Some people prefer “with disabilities” but generally “disabled” is fine, and is preferred by most disabled people I know, especially those active in disability rights 😊 Avoid euphemisms like “differently-abled” though.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JezzChung Everyone has their own preference! Some people prefer \xe2\x80\x9cwith disabilities\xe2\x80\x9d but generally \xe2\x80\x9cdisabled\xe2\x80\x9d is fine, and is preferred by most disabled people I know, especially those active in disability rights \xf0\x9f\x98\x8a Avoid euphemisms like \xe2\x80\x9cdifferently-abled\xe2\x80\x9d though.'

full_text: @eerriinn__ Please don’t use autism as an example to promote people-first language. Obviously it’s up to the individual, and some do prefer PFL, but a majority of autistic people prefer “autistic” over “with autism.

full_text: @kat_blaque People who use PFL often see autism as separate from the person, and often (not always) see it as a disease we should try to cure. Those who use IFL are more likely to be pro autism acceptance and see it as a fundamental part of who someone is, rather than something they “have”.

full_text: @Nik_4man I mean, it’s how our brains are wired so it kind of is who we are. Why do we need to be “more” than that?  And using an adjective doesn’t mean that’s all someone is. If someone’s described as “artistic” then you don’t say “oh no, you’re so much more than that”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Nik_4man I mean, it\xe2\x80\x99s how our brains are wired so it kind of is who we are. Why do we need to be \xe2\x80\x9cmore\xe2\x80\x9d than that?  And using an adjective doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that\xe2\x80\x99s all someone is. If someone\xe2\x80\x99s described as \xe2\x80\x9cartistic\xe2\x80\x9d then you don\xe2\x80\x99t say \xe2\x80\x9coh no, you\xe2\x80\x99re so much more than that\xe2\x80\x9d.'

full_text: @Nik_4man for things that are seen as neutral or positive (“she is creative”, “he is gay”, “they’re American” etc”). For many of us being autistic is a fundamental part of who we are. It’s not an illness or a disease so it doesn’t feel right to say we “have it”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Nik_4man for things that are seen as neutral or positive (\xe2\x80\x9cshe is creative\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9che is gay\xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re American\xe2\x80\x9d etc\xe2\x80\x9d). full_text: @Nik_4man of wording for a lot of negative things (“with cancer” etc). On the other hand, the adjective “autistic” feels more neutral. It describes who the person is, rather than positioning autism as something they “have”. We often use this type of phrasing
full_text(utf-8): b'@Nik_4man of wording for a lot of negative things (\xe2\x80\x9cwith cancer\xe2\x80\x9d etc). On the other hand, the adjective \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d feels more neutral. It describes who the person is, rather than positioning autism as something they \xe2\x80\x9chave\xe2\x80\x9d. We often use this type of phrasing'

full_text: @Nik_4man PFL seeks to separate a person from their autism, encouraging people to see it as something that person *has* rather than part of who they are. This leads to people seeing autism as an illness and potentially to advocating for harmful treatments or cures. We tend to use this type
full_text(utf-8): b'@Nik_4man PFL seeks to separate a person from their autism, encouraging people to see it as something that person *has* rather than part of who they are. This leads to people seeing autism as an illness and potentially to advocating for harmful treatments or cures. We tend to use this type'

full_text: @Nik_4man It’s really concerning that this is still so widely taught 😔 PFL is considered stigmatising and offensive by many autistic people and yet for some reason a lot of educators continue to speak over us and insist upon it.

full_text: @onlyasmile_away @autistictic Part of the issue with PFL is that it makes autism a noun rather than an adjective, creating a separation between the person and their autism. The phrase “autistic people” doesn’t do this. Use of the word person or people doesn’t make something PFL.
full_text(utf-8): b'@onlyasmile_away @autistictic Part of the issue with PFL is that it makes autism a noun rather than an adjective, creating a separation between the person and their autism. The phrase \xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do this. Use of the word person or people doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make something PFL.'

full_text: @marrymek8walsh @KEEMSTAR @TommyNC2010 If you’re autistic and prefer “with autism” for yourself then obviously that’s up to you, but it’s not a general rule. Most autistic people tend to use identity/condition first language rather than people-first.
full_text(utf-8): b'@marrymek8walsh @KEEMSTAR @TommyNC2010 If you\xe2\x80\x99re autistic and prefer \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d for yourself then obviously that\xe2\x80\x99s up to you, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not a general rule. Most autistic people tend to use identity/condition first language rather than people-first.'

full_text: @autistictic For example it feels ok (I think? Please correct me if I’m wrong) to say “lesbians” or “Christians” rather than “lesbian people” or “Christian people”, but I would always say “gay people” or “Black people” rather than “gays” or “blacks”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@autistictic For example it feels ok (I think? Please correct me if I\xe2\x80\x99m wrong) to say \xe2\x80\x9clesbians\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cChristians\xe2\x80\x9d rather than \xe2\x80\x9clesbian people\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cChristian people\xe2\x80\x9d, but I would always say \xe2\x80\x9cgay people\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cBlack people\xe2\x80\x9d rather than \xe2\x80\x9cgays\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cblacks\xe2\x80\x9d.'

full_text: @autistictic I don’t have a problem with it per se, but I find it’s heavily dependent on context, tone, the person who is talking etc. It’s interesting to compare it to how we talk about other groups, because for some it feels fine and for others it doesn’t?
full_text(utf-8): b'@autistictic I don\xe2\x80\x99t have a problem with it per se, but I find it\xe2\x80\x99s heavily dependent on context, tone, the person who is talking etc. It\xe2\x80\x99s interesting to compare it to how we talk about other groups, because for some it feels fine and for others it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t?'

full_text: @onlyasmile_away @autistictic Saying “I’m autistic” is identity-first language, the same way that saying “autistic people” or “autistic person” is. Person-first would be saying “I have autism” or “people with autism”. Using “autistic(s)” as a noun is different from either of these.
full_text(utf-8): b'@onlyasmile_away @autistictic Saying \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m autistic\xe2\x80\x9d is identity-first language, the same way that saying \xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cautistic person\xe2\x80\x9d is. Person-first would be saying \xe2\x80\x9cI have autism\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cpeople with autism\xe2\x80\x9d. Using \xe2\x80\x9cautistic(s)\xe2\x80\x9d as a noun is different from either of these.'

full_text: @AnnaCheavens Autism is not an illness. It’s not something someone “has”, so it doesn’t make sense to try to separate a person from their autism and somehow “see one before the other”. It’s just nonsensical. Some may prefer it, but in general this is something non-autistics try to force on us.
full_text(utf-8): b'@AnnaCheavens Autism is not an illness. full_text: @squid_666 The thing is, there are many barriers to formal diagnosis (as well as various reasons someone may not want one), so it’s not always as simple as just going out and getting evaluated. The autistic community in general is pretty supportive of self-diagnosis.

full_text: @JabaTheChris @PamKeithFL “Autistic” is fine unless you happen to know the person in question prefers “with autism”. Obviously it’s up to the individual, but people-first language is very unpopular with much of the autistic community and is often seen as stigmatising and offensive.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JabaTheChris @PamKeithFL \xe2\x80\x9cAutistic\xe2\x80\x9d is fine unless you happen to know the person in question prefers \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d. full_text:
5am this morning, trying to snuggle my (mostly non-verbal) three year-old back to sleep.

Him: NO! 
Me: What?
Him: Stop...sniffing!
Me: I’m not sniffing. I’m just breathing.
Him: Stop breathing.

😂

full_text: @melissasmith429 Many people feel like “person with...” creates an artificial separation between a person and their autism- as if it’s a kind of “add on” rather than something integral to who they are. People only seem to insist on person first language for things they see as negative...

full_text: @agender_avian Maybe they’re still using the old criteria, which distinguished autism from Asperger’s specifically by whether or not someone had delayed language. That’s not used in the US (or many other places) anymore, as far as I know.

full_text: @brittanymagsig @aheeleyRIBA So whilst some people do prefer person-first language (which is obviously fine), many of us dislike it because it misguidedly attempts to separate the person we are from “our autism”, which can be harmful. I do appreciate that this is not what’s widely taught.
full_text(utf-8): b'@brittanymagsig @aheeleyRIBA So whilst some people do prefer person-first language (which is obviously fine), many of us dislike it because it misguidedly attempts to separate the person we are from \xe2\x80\x9cour autism\xe2\x80\x9d, which can be harmful. I do appreciate that this is not what\xe2\x80\x99s widely taught.'

full_text: @brittanymagsig @aheeleyRIBA This attitude is well intentioned but it’s rooted in ableism. To be autistic is to have your brain wired a certain way. It informs and influences everything about a person, and whilst most of us do consider it a disability, that is NOT necessarily a bad thing.
full_text(utf-8): b'@brittanymagsig @aheeleyRIBA This attitude is well intentioned but it\xe2\x80\x99s rooted in ableism. To be autistic is to have your brain wired a certain way. It informs and influences everything about a person, and whilst most of us do consider it a disability, that is NOT necessarily a bad thing.'

full_text: @TheCertainUnce1 @autisticpastor There’s a good amount of research showing that most autistic people prefer “autistic person” over “person with autism”. It’s not really polite to tell someone else how they should identify.
full_text(utf-8): b'@TheCertainUnce1 @autisticpastor There\xe2\x80\x99s a good amount of research showing that most autistic people prefer \xe2\x80\x9cautistic person\xe2\x80\x9d over \xe2\x80\x9cperson with autism\xe2\x80\x9d. It\xe2\x80\x99s not really polite to tell someone else how they should identify.'

full_text:
@AutismTalkAspie The “correct” term is whatever the person in question prefers. When speaking in general terms (or if you don’t know someone’s preference) then it makes sense to use “autistic person” as that’s the majority preference. Pretty simple.

Also, non-autistic people shouldn’t be voting.
full_text(utf-8): b'@AutismTalkAspie The \xe2\x80\x9ccorrect\xe2\x80\x9d term is whatever the person in question prefers. full_text: @MissSantillo Also, for many of us in the autistic community, autism awareness week/month is a deeply upsetting and difficult time, as we are held up as objects of pity and spoken over and belittled by non-autistics. That’s why some promote #AcceptanceNotAwareness.
full_text(utf-8): b'@MissSantillo Also, for many of us in the autistic community, autism awareness week/month is a deeply upsetting and difficult time, as we are held up as objects of pity and spoken over and belittled by non-autistics. That\xe2\x80\x99s why some promote #AcceptanceNotAwareness.'

full_text: @MissSantillo Most autistic people prefer “autistic people”. Some prefer person-first language but in general it’s pretty unpopular in the autistic community. Also, the “despite their disability” stuff is *really* offensive.

full_text: @ClearAutism Yes that’s definitely something we’ll consider. There are schools that would be perfect but unfortunately they’re already full ☹️ I don’t know how some people seem to get everything sorted so quickly - things like diagnosis, EHCP etc all just seem to be a lottery.
full_text(utf-8): b'@ClearAutism Yes that\xe2\x80\x99s definitely something we\xe2\x80\x99ll consider. There are schools that would be perfect but unfortunately they\xe2\x80\x99re already full \xe2\x98\xb9\xef\xb8\x8f I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how some people seem to get everything sorted so quickly - things like diagnosis, EHCP etc all just seem to be a lottery.'

full_text: @ClearAutism They’ve been nice about it, but are just very honest about the fact that demand for specialist provision vastly outweighs the availability, so if we get offered *anything* we should snap it up. The problem is that the provision varies from “amazing” to “horrible”.

full_text(utf-8): b'@Lindsie_Rose @aheeleyRIBA Personally I would always call myself autistic (never \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d), but I\xe2\x80\x99d always say I have depression, rather than calling myself a depressive. full_text: @Lindsie_Rose @aheeleyRIBA There’s no universal rule. Individuals have their own preferences, and different communities have different majority views. What is true for most autistic people may not be true for most people with Down Syndrome for example.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Lindsie_Rose @aheeleyRIBA There\xe2\x80\x99s no universal rule. Individuals have their own preferences, and different communities have different majority views. What is true for most autistic people may not be true for most people with Down Syndrome for example.'

full_text: @Lindsie_Rose There’s been quite a lot of research. If the question is asked of autistic people *only*, then “autistic” comes out on top. If it’s open to everyone then more people seem to like “has autism”, because that’s what non-autistic people seem to think is better for some reason 🤷‍♀️
full_text(utf-8): b'@Lindsie_Rose There\xe2\x80\x99s been quite a lot of research. If the question is asked of autistic people *only*, then \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d comes out on top. full_text: @Lindsie_Rose Obviously it depends on the individual’s preference, but I would default to “Mike is autistic”, as this is the language preferred by most autistic people. Person-first language is widely disliked in the autistic community.

full_text: @Aspertypical I generally say non-autistic. “Without autism” has the same problems as “with autism”. Neurotypical and typically developed don’t mean the same thing as “non-autistic”. Allistic isn’t understood by a lot of people.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Aspertypical I generally say non-autistic. \xe2\x80\x9cWithout autism\xe2\x80\x9d has the same problems as \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d. Neurotypical and typically developed don\xe2\x80\x99t mean the same thing as \xe2\x80\x9cnon-autistic\xe2\x80\x9d. Allistic isn\xe2\x80\x99t understood by a lot of people.'

full_text: @TheElderMemes Left out. I loved the game but had to quit because I’m autistic and it’s too painful to see my neurology used as an insult with absolutely zero consequences. It’s not #TESforALL until this ableism is dealt with.

full_text: @Dreyia4 @aheeleyRIBA @jared_liesey @cybxrsxd @Timkent95 @matt951817 @JimmysSeafood @peta @NFL @FOXSports I don’t understand your point. You’re saying “majority rules”, but the majority prefers to say “autistic”?
full_text(utf-8): b'@Dreyia4 @aheeleyRIBA @jared_liesey @cybxrsxd @Timkent95 @matt951817 @JimmysSeafood @peta @NFL @FOXSports I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand your point. You\xe2\x80\x99re saying \xe2\x80\x9cmajority rules\xe2\x80\x9d, but the majority prefers to say \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d?'

full_text: @Dreyia4 @aheeleyRIBA @jared_liesey @cybxrsxd @Timkent95 @matt951817 @JimmysSeafood @peta @NFL @FOXSports Obviously some people do prefer to say they “have autism” or they’re “a person with autism”, and obviously that’s totally fine, but it’s pretty well-established that they’re in the minority. In general it’s absolutely fine to say “autistic”!
full_text(utf-8): b'@Dreyia4 @aheeleyRIBA @jared_liesey @cybxrsxd @Timkent95 @matt951817 @JimmysSeafood @peta @NFL @FOXSports Obviously some people do prefer to say they \xe2\x80\x9chave autism\xe2\x80\x9d or they\xe2\x80\x99re \xe2\x80\x9ca person with autism\xe2\x80\x9d, and obviously that\xe2\x80\x99s totally fine, but it\xe2\x80\x99s pretty well-established that they\xe2\x80\x99re in the minority. In general it\xe2\x80\x99s absolutely fine to say \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d!'

full_text: @Dreyia4 @aheeleyRIBA @jared_liesey @cybxrsxd @Timkent95 @matt951817 @JimmysSeafood @peta @NFL @FOXSports There have been so many polls though, of thousands of people. Members of the autistic community have been writing about why “person first language” is problematic for over 20 years. Autistic-led organisations almost exclusively use “autistic”.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Dreyia4 @aheeleyRIBA @jared_liesey @cybxrsxd @Timkent95 @matt951817 @JimmysSeafood @peta @NFL @FOXSports There have been so many polls though, of thousands of people. full_text: @EnnsKendall @MirandaRoll Not sure who you mean by “we”, but most autistic people prefer “autistic people” over “people with autism”. If you prefer the latter for yourself then obviously that’s cool, but in general there’s nothing wrong with the word autistic.
full_text(utf-8): b'@EnnsKendall @MirandaRoll Not sure who you mean by \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x9d, but most autistic people prefer \xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d over \xe2\x80\x9cpeople with autism\xe2\x80\x9d. If you prefer the latter for yourself then obviously that\xe2\x80\x99s cool, but in general there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing wrong with the word autistic.'

full_text: @JoshThomas87 Obviously everyone has their own preference which should be used wherever possible, but when speaking in general terms I just use “autistic”. I know plenty of people are fine with “on the spectrum”, but others find it euphemistic and misleading.
full_text(utf-8): b'@JoshThomas87 Obviously everyone has their own preference which should be used wherever possible, but when speaking in general terms I just use \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d. full_text: @JoshThomas87 There have been quite a lot of surveys (several of > 10k people) and “autistic” always comes out as preferred by most autistic folk. Non-autistic parents and especially professionals are more likely to prefer “with autism”.

full_text: @AaronHosford @IAmJessPlant @Sara_Rose_G There are exceptions (I know of a couple of British Saras who pronounce it like Sarah). In British English names like Tara, Mara and Cara all generally rhyme with Sara but not with Sarah.
full_text(utf-8): b'@AaronHosford @IAmJessPlant @Sara_Rose_G There are exceptions (I know of a couple of British Saras who pronounce it like Sarah). In British English names like Tara, Mara and Cara all generally rhyme with Sara but not with Sarah.'

full_text: @AaronHosford @IAmJessPlant @Sara_Rose_G US vs UK. I believe that typically in the US Sara and Sarah are pronounced the same (SAIR-uh), with the first syllable rhyming with care/bare/fare. In the UK Sara is usually pronounced SAH-ruh, with the first syllable rhyming with car/bar/far.
full_text(utf-8): b'@AaronHosford @IAmJessPlant @Sara_Rose_G US vs UK. full_text: @brookewinters33 It takes almost everything out of me. Online I *need* to limit my activism to a small, specific issue because otherwise I’d get completely burnt out. This is what I choose to focus on. It may seem insignificant but I like to think it makes a difference in some small way.
full_text(utf-8): b'@brookewinters33 It takes almost everything out of me. Online I *need* to limit my activism to a small, specific issue because otherwise I\xe2\x80\x99d get completely burnt out. This is what I choose to focus on. It may seem insignificant but I like to think it makes a difference in some small way.'

full_text: @brookewinters33 I personally choose to focus on PFL/IFL as an issue because, for me, it’s what I’m comfortable with. I spend my time offline not just existing as an autistic person (difficult), but also caring for and advocating for my young son who has high support needs.
full_text(utf-8): b'@brookewinters33 I personally choose to focus on PFL/IFL as an issue because, for me, it\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m comfortable with. full_text: @LeahMFraser @marsforhastings @DisabledWarRoom @Adamqab We say autistic because that’s what most autistic people prefer and it’s respectful to use the majority preference. full_text:
Watching a (non-sci-fi) tv show and there are two characters who look exactly the same.

Husband: Why is there a CLONE!?

Me: ...you’re familiar with the concept of identical twins?

Husband (an actual identical twin): ...
full_text(utf-8):
b'Watching a (non-sci-fi) tv show and there are two characters who look exactly the same.

full_text: @acexarofierro I use subtitles because I’m autistic and have audio processing difficulties. I *can* watch without them but I don’t pick up on everything that’s being said and I find it much harder to follow the plot. Subtitles also help me focus - without them my attention often drifts.

full_text: @chadloder @jeffsecblog It’s stigmatising because it deliberately positions autism as something which is separate from the self. People only tend to do with characteristics they see as negative, or things like diseases.
full_text(utf-8): b'@chadloder @jeffsecblog It\xe2\x80\x99s stigmatising because it deliberately positions autism as something which is separate from the self. People only tend to do with characteristics they see as negative, or things like diseases.'

full_text: @jeffsecblog @chadloder People-first language isn’t necessarily “correct”. It’s actually quite unpopular with many autistic people, most of whom prefer “autistic person” over “person with autism”, largely because they do tend to consider it something they *are* and not something they *have*.
full_text(utf-8): b'@jeffsecblog @chadloder People-first language isn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily \xe2\x80\x9ccorrect\xe2\x80\x9d. It\xe2\x80\x99s actually quite unpopular with many autistic people, most of whom prefer \xe2\x80\x9cautistic person\xe2\x80\x9d over \xe2\x80\x9cperson with autism\xe2\x80\x9d, largely because they do tend to consider it something they *are* and not something they *have*.'

full_text: @shivshiveshakes This is a subject that’s been written about and discussed at some length by autistic people. With respect, if you’re not autistic then it’s not really appropriate to speak over us on the subject
full_text(utf-8): b'@shivshiveshakes This is a subject that\xe2\x80\x99s been written about and discussed at some length by autistic people. With respect, if you\xe2\x80\x99re not autistic then it\xe2\x80\x99s not really appropriate to speak over us on the subject'

full_text: @shivshiveshakes Yeah, there’s no one term that’s unanimously favoured, but identity first language is preferred by a decent majority of autistic people so it makes sense to use it by default. Look at the language used by autistic-led organisations such as ASAN, AWN, Autistic UK etc.
full_text(utf-8): b'@shivshiveshakes Yeah, there\xe2\x80\x99s no one term that\xe2\x80\x99s unanimously favoured, but identity first language is preferred by a decent majority of autistic people so it makes sense to use it by default. Look at the language used by autistic-led organisations such as ASAN, AWN, Autistic UK etc.'

full_text: @shivshiveshakes Sorry, but the opinions of doctors etc don’t get to take priority over the opinions of actual autistic people. If someone prefers it for themselves then fine, but person-first language is considered offensive and stigmatising by many autistic people.
full_text(utf-8): b'@shivshiveshakes Sorry, but the opinions of doctors etc don\xe2\x80\x99t get to take priority over the opinions of actual autistic people. If someone prefers it for themselves then fine, but person-first language is considered offensive and stigmatising by many autistic people.'

full_text: @autism_by It’s less about what wording is actually being used and more about the fact that non-autistic people constantly speak over autistic people in an attempt to police and control our language. We should be the ones who get to choose.
full_text(utf-8): b'@autism_by It\xe2\x80\x99s less about what wording is actually being used and more about the fact that non-autistic people constantly speak over autistic people in an attempt to police and control our language. We should be the ones who get to choose.'

full_text: @shivshiveshakes This is not generally the best language to use regarding autism, unless you know an individual happens to prefer it. Most autistic people prefer identity-first language. Person-first can be considered stigmatising and offensive.

full_text: @7BOURNEY @PaddyMcGuinness Eligibility is no longer based solely on physical ability to walk. There are reasons autistic people (and others with hidden disabilities) may need a blue badge, even if they can physically walk. It’s not for random passers-by to decide if someone deserves their blue badge!
full_text(utf-8): b'@7BOURNEY @PaddyMcGuinness Eligibility is no longer based solely on physical ability to walk. There are reasons autistic people (and others with hidden disabilities) may need a blue badge, even if they can physically walk. It\xe2\x80\x99s not for random passers-by to decide if someone deserves their blue badge!'

full_text: @MrsHJSheridan @PaddyMcGuinness That’s the point: not all disabilities are visible. It would be different if someone without a blue badge was using the space, but if they have a blue badge they are entitled to park there and shouldn’t be challenged, even if they may not “appear” disabled to others.
full_text(utf-8): b'@MrsHJSheridan @PaddyMcGuinness That\xe2\x80\x99s the point: not all disabilities are visible. full_text: @emyleemercedes No, saying “the autistic man” is like saying “the brown-haired man”. It’s fine, it’s just an adjective. Identity-first language is used and preferred by a majority in the autistic community. Look at the language used by autistic-led organisations for example.
full_text(utf-8): b'@emyleemercedes No, saying \xe2\x80\x9cthe autistic man\xe2\x80\x9d is like saying \xe2\x80\x9cthe brown-haired man\xe2\x80\x9d. full_text: @stefaniangelise Obviously everyone has their own preference, but most autistic people prefer “autistic people” over “people with autism” (just how you wouldn’t say “people with whiteness” or “people with homosexuality” instead of white or gay). It’s just an adjective.

full_text: @DuncanBannatyne I’m autistic, as is my son. We don’t “suffer” from autism and we don’t need “curing” because there’s nothing wrong with us. This is who we are! full_text: @NeuroRebel I do tell some people I have Asperger’s when it feels safer or easier for me to do so, but tbh I always feel uncomfortable about it. I think it’s really important that we all get to choose how we identify and respect people who choose differently though.

full_text: @NeuroRebel I’m diagnosed both Asperger’s and ASD but I say I’m autistic. I think the lines dividing AS and ASD are arbitrary and unhelpful and I find the term divisive. I also hate the word “aspie” from an aesthetic point of view, but I’d never tell someone else how they should identify.

full_text: @PerplexedSeal @somethinghappen @thisniss Also, describing someone as “autistic” doesn’t mean that’s all there is to them, or that “defines them”. It’s just an adjective, like tall, or white, or creative, or bisexual. There’s nothing wrong with identity-first language.

full_text: @Playa_Naya @aheeleyRIBA @chiassoso @amanda_ferner The autistic community uses the hashtag #ActuallyAutistic, not “ActuallyWithAutism”. full_text: @rickydhouse @SrslyNotBoring @autisticpastor @soycourt @Kalarigamerchic It absolutely depends on the person. full_text: @spacedoutsmiles @Shona_Mu The bow tie thing was mercifully ditched when you reached the third year of senior school. In the sixth form we had a little more freedom (any conservative navy or grey skirt, for example, and no blazers ), but it was still fairly strict.
full_text(utf-8): b'@spacedoutsmiles @Shona_Mu The bow tie thing was mercifully ditched when you reached the third year of senior school. In the sixth form we had a little more freedom (any conservative navy or grey skirt, for example, and no blazers ), but it was still fairly strict.'

full_text: @Shona_Mu @spacedoutsmiles The jumper was optional, but you weren’t allowed to remove the bow, take off your jacket, roll up your sleeves, wear trousers instead of a skirt (or a comfier skirt) or socks instead of tights, until the headmaster decreed that the weather was warm enough.

full_text: @kdavis135 @Dominic__Noble “With autism” is the wording preferred by most non-autistic professionals, but it’s *not* preferred by most autistic people. It’s important to find out someone’s personal preference wherever possible as a lot of people feel very strongly about this.
full_text(utf-8): b'@kdavis135 @Dominic__Noble \xe2\x80\x9cWith autism\xe2\x80\x9d is the wording preferred by most non-autistic professionals, but it\xe2\x80\x99s *not* preferred by most autistic people. It\xe2\x80\x99s important to find out someone\xe2\x80\x99s personal preference wherever possible as a lot of people feel very strongly about this.'

full_text: @SaraAnne_1021 @WSMV *Obviously everyone had their own preference and if someone prefers “with autism” then that needs to be respected.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SaraAnne_1021 @WSMV *Obviously everyone had their own preference and if someone prefers \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d then that needs to be respected.'

full_text: @SaraAnne_1021 @WSMV You may want to look at the language used by autistic-led advocacy organizations such as ASAN and AWN; they tend to say “autistic” instead of “with autism”. There have also been multiple surveys of thousands of autistic people which show that this wording is more popular.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SaraAnne_1021 @WSMV You may want to look at the language used by autistic-led advocacy organizations such as ASAN and AWN; they tend to say \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d instead of \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d. There have also been multiple surveys of thousands of autistic people which show that this wording is more popular.'

full_text: @SaraAnne_1021 @WSMV There’s nothing wrong with identity-first language (“autistic people”) when it comes to autism. Most autistic people actually tend to prefer it. Person-first language is preferred by some communities and individuals but it isn’t a hard and fast rule.
full_text(utf-8): b'@SaraAnne_1021 @WSMV There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing wrong with identity-first language (\xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d) when it comes to autism. Most autistic people actually tend to prefer it. Person-first language is preferred by some communities and individuals but it isn\xe2\x80\x99t a hard and fast rule.'

full_text: @Sara_Rose_G It’s been ten years since my cat died and in that time I’ve lost human family members I loved very much. That didn’t lessen the loss of my cat or “put it in perspective” at all because that’s not how these things work.
full_text(utf-8): b'@Sara_Rose_G It\xe2\x80\x99s been ten years since my cat died and in that time I\xe2\x80\x99ve lost human family members I loved very much. That didn\xe2\x80\x99t lessen the loss of my cat or \xe2\x80\x9cput it in perspective\xe2\x80\x9d at all because that\xe2\x80\x99s not how these things work.'

full_text: @Sara_Rose_G Ugh, no, fuck these people trying to belittle your grief. When I lost my cat suddenly I had to take a full week off work because I was literally vomiting with pain and couldn’t hold it together. Maybe it’s different for us autistics. We feel differently, maybe more?

full_text: @dontclareenough @itsmeshaunae @lilliant_13 @ajaaax_ Often when autistic people say they “don’t have autism” it’s not about avoiding reality, or about saying autism isn’t a disability. It’s about stressing that autism is part of *who we are*, not a separate thing that we *have*. Hope that makes sense, it’s late here 💤

full_text: @JessMocci I know this gets taught as the “correct” language a lot, but it shouldn’t really be promoted as a hard and fast rule. Many disabled people prefer to be called “disabled”. Autistic people in particular tend to prefer identity-first language (“autistic people”).
full_text(utf-8): b'@JessMocci I know this gets taught as the \xe2\x80\x9ccorrect\xe2\x80\x9d language a lot, but it shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t really be promoted as a hard and fast rule. Many disabled people prefer to be called \xe2\x80\x9cdisabled\xe2\x80\x9d. Autistic people in particular tend to prefer identity-first language (\xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d).'

full_text: @BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA We know that people are taught that person-first language is correct. This is because they’re so often taught by non-autistic people who don’t listen to or engage with the people they’re talking about in any meaningful way. It’s why “Nothing About Us Without Us” is so important.

full_text: @BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA If you take the time to look at the language used by #ActuallyAutistic people and autistic-led organizations like ASAN and AWN, you’ll see that the autistic community (in general) has a very different opionion than what you’ve probably been taught by non-autistic educators.
full_text(utf-8): b'@BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA If you take the time to look at the language used by #ActuallyAutistic people and autistic-led organizations like ASAN and AWN, you\xe2\x80\x99ll see that the autistic community (in general) has a very different opionion than what you\xe2\x80\x99ve probably been taught by non-autistic educators.'

full_text: @BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA Some people aren’t bothered either way, but for many this is a really important issue and it needs to be respected. You wouldn’t say someone “has homosexuality” or “has whiteness”, and for many this is similar. Autism is not something that is separate from the person.

full_text: @BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA There has been so much research into this subject, and anyone who engages with the autistic community (not the “autism community” - not the same thing) knows that *most* of us use identity-first language (“autistic people”) over person-first (“people with autism”).
full_text(utf-8): b'@BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA There has been so much research into this subject, and anyone who engages with the autistic community (not the \xe2\x80\x9cautism community\xe2\x80\x9d - not the same thing) knows that *most* of us use identity-first language (\xe2\x80\x9cautistic people\xe2\x80\x9d) over person-first (\xe2\x80\x9cpeople with autism\xe2\x80\x9d).'

full_text: @BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA Listen, I’m sure you mean well, but autistic people go through this every day. The fact that you work with autistic children is not the same as having lived experience of being autistic, and it doesn’t give you a say in things like the language we use.

@BeLovidLily @aheeleyRIBA Oh wow, where to start...? 

Firstly, functioning labels are pretty outdated and unhelpful. Secondly, non-verbal/high support needs doesn’t mean someone can’t have an opinion. Thirdly, why on earth would you think that non-autistic people get any kind of say in this?

full_text: @KimmRogers @justfinethanx @Rosie @DVATW Well, most of us don’t say we “have autism”. It’s literally the way our brains our wired. full_text: @Alexandria_Lee7 @JBell_26 Sorry, I would agree with the other comments. Whilst person-first language seems to be taught as a hard and fast rule, this doesn’t always take into account the opinions of the people being talked about. full_text: @MentalBreakThru @PerplexedSeal @AmbitiousAutism Many local authorities don’t accept private diagnoses. Also things like DLA, EHCP etc are all supposed to be based on needs rather than diagnosis, so there’s no guarantee that one will actually get you anything. We decided to spend our money on speech therapy instead.

full_text: @TheAspieWorld I have a dual diagnosis of Asperger’s and ASD but I just say I’m autistic as I think it’s more inclusive. full_text: @terrypal123 @KL_allemand @lenoretaylor Sorry, this isn’t correct. Her diagnosis is Asperger’s, which specifically does not include a delay in spoken language. She’s still autistic though. Lots of autistic people are very verbally articulate.
full_text(utf-8): b'@terrypal123 @KL_allemand @lenoretaylor Sorry, this isn\xe2\x80\x99t correct. Her diagnosis is Asperger\xe2\x80\x99s, which specifically does not include a delay in spoken language. She\xe2\x80\x99s still autistic though. Lots of autistic people are very verbally articulate.'

b'@MsVeruca - Neurodivergent and autistic don\xe2\x80\x99t mean the same thing. You can be neurodivergent and not autistic.
- Not all autistic people have superpowers or amazing gifts. 

If you want informed opinions try asking actual autistic people. You can use the hashtag #AskingAutistics.  4/4'

b'@MsVeruca - Just because an autistic person may appear highly capable, this does not mean they are not also disabled in some ways.\n- Most autistic people prefer to be called \xe2\x80\x9cautistic\xe2\x80\x9d rather than \xe2\x80\x9cwith autism\xe2\x80\x9d.\n- \xe2\x80\x9cAutistic\xe2\x80\x9d is not an outdated or offensive term. 3/'

b'@MsVeruca - Terms like mild/severe and high/low functioning are outdated and unhelpful.\n- Non-verbal does not mean someone is unintelligent or that they don\xe2\x80\x99t understand.\n- Asperger\xe2\x80\x99s is autism. 2/'

b'@MsVeruca I am disappointed at how ignorant (if well-meaning) some of the replies to this have been. To clear a few things up:

- No, we are not all \xe2\x80\x9csomewhere on the spectrum\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9ca little bit autistic\xe2\x80\x9d.
- The autism spectrum is not linear so it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have \xe2\x80\x9cends\xe2\x80\x9d.  1/'

full_text: @MsVeruca For me, autism is best described as a neurological difference. It is also a disability for many people (some people feel strongly about this one way or the other) which does not make it a bad thing.

full_text: @MsVeruca Autism is not an intellectual impairment. Some autistic people may have an intellectual disability, but so may non-autistic people. Greta’s diagnosis (not used anymore in most places) is Asperger’s Syndrome which specifically precludes any kind of intellectual impairment.

@JoeAbraham5 movements. Racing games for example, I am terrible at. I’m always going fully to the left or fully to the right, I can’t do gradual or subtle movements.
The bigger issue for me is the ableism in the gaming community. “Autistic” is used as an insult everywhere and it’s awful.

full_text: @dparzych I can’t speak for anyone else. AFAIK most blind and d/Deaf people prefer identity-first language, most people with Down Syndrome and learning/intellectual disabilities prefer PFL. I tend to use “disabled” by default when speaking in general because that’s what I see used most.
full_text(utf-8): b'@dparzych I can\xe2\x80\x99t speak for anyone else. I tend to use \xe2\x80\x9cdisabled\xe2\x80\x9d by default when speaking in general because that\xe2\x80\x99s what I see used most.'

full_text: @KIDS_CEO @IgHawthorne I spent hours upon hours detailing my autistic son’s difficulties (for DLA) and sent reports from multiple professionals to corroborate, only to be refused and told there was “no evidence” for anything I’d said. The wait for an appeal date is almost a year.

full_text: @jordph @mr_runskiclimb @AndrewGillum Most autistic people actually prefer identity-first language. In this case it’s person-first that can be stigmatising because it frames autism as something separate from the person, like a disease, rather than a fundamental part of their neurology.
